title: Charles Mullins
text:
Major Charles Herbert Mullins <a href="Victoria%20Cross">VC</a> <a href="Order%20of%20St%20Michael%20and%20St%20George">CMG</a> (28 June 1869 – 24 May 1916) was a <a href="South%20Africa">South African</a> recipient of the <a href="Victoria%20Cross">Victoria Cross</a>, the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> and <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth</a> forces.
Details.
Mullins was 30 years old, and a <a href="Captain%20%28land%20and%20air%29">captain</a> in the <a href="Light%20Horse%20Regiment">Imperial Light Horse (Natal)</a> during the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a> when the following deed took place at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Elandslaagte">Battle of Elandslaagte</a> for which he and Captain <a href="Robert%20Johnston%20%28VC%29">Robert Johnston</a> were awarded the VC.
Mullins returned to the United Kingdom and received the VC from <a href="Edward%20VII">King Edward VII</a> during an investiture at <a href="Marlborough%20House">Marlborough House</a> 25 July 1901.
He later achieved the rank of <a href="major">major</a>.
The medal was held by <a href="St.%20Andrew%27s%20College%2C%20Grahamstown">St. Andrew's College, Grahamstown</a>, South Africa. It was later returned to the family and is now on loan to the <a href="Imperial%20War%20Museum">Imperial War Museum</a>, <a href="London">London</a>.
Clarles was the son of the Revd Canon <a href="Robert%20John%20Mullins%20%28priest%29">Robert John Mullins</a>, and brother to <a href="Robert%20George%20Mullins%20%28priest%29">Robert George Mullins</a>, the founder of <a href="St.%20Andrew%27s%20Preparatory%20School">St. Andrew's Preparatory School</a> in Grahamstown.
